fact: A triangle’s angles always sum up to 180 degrees.
A square is a rectangle with all sides equal in length.
The sum of the interior angles of any quadrilateral is 360 degrees.
A regular polygon has all sides and all angles equal.
In an isosceles triangle, at least two sides are of equal length.
A diameter of a circle is the longest possible chord of that circle.
All radii of a given circle are equal in length.
A right angle measures exactly 90 degrees.
An acute angle measures less than 90 degrees.
An obtuse angle measures greater than 90 degrees but less than 180 degrees.
A straight angle measures exactly 180 degrees.
A parallelogram is a quadrilateral where opposite sides are parallel and equal.
Opposite angles in a parallelogram are equal.
A trapezoid (or trapezium) has at least one pair of parallel sides.
The angles on a straight line sum up to 180 degrees.
The sum of the interior angles of a pentagon is 540 degrees.
The sum of the interior angles of a hexagon is 720 degrees.
The shortest distance from a point to a line is always a perpendicular line.
All angles in an equilateral triangle measure 60 degrees.
A rhombus is a parallelogram with four equal sides.
A square is a rhombus with right angles.
In a circle, the circumference is π times the diameter.
A tangent to a circle is perpendicular to the radius at the point of tangency.
The sum of the exterior angles of any polygon, one at each vertex, is always 360 degrees.
Similar polygons have angles that are equal and sides that are in proportion.
Congruent figures have the same shape and size.
In a right triangle, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides (Pythagorean theorem).
A circle has an infinite number of lines of symmetry.
An equilateral triangle is also equiangular, and vice versa.
In a circle, a chord that passes through the center is a diameter.
The sum of the interior angles of a triangle is always the same, no matter what the shape of the triangle is.
A polygon with all angles less than 180 degrees is called a convex polygon.
A polygon with at least one angle greater than 180 degrees is called a concave polygon.
In a regular polygon, each interior angle can be calculated using the formula: (n-2)*180°/n, where n is the number of sides.
All squares are rectangles, but not all rectangles are squares.
A kite is a quadrilateral with two pairs of adjacent sides equal.
The angle bisector of a triangle divides the opposite side into segments proportional to the adjacent sides.
The perpendicular bisector of a line segment is the set of all points equidistant from the segment’s endpoints.
If two angles are complementary, they sum to 90 degrees.
If two angles are supplementary, they sum to 180 degrees.
A regular hexagon can be divided into 6 equilateral triangles.
A regular pentagon has 5 lines of symmetry.
A square has 4 lines of symmetry.
An equilateral triangle has 3 lines of symmetry.
A circle has a constant radius at every point on its circumference.
Parallel lines never intersect, no matter how far they are extended.
A transversal line crossing parallel lines creates corresponding angles that are equal.
The altitude (height) of a triangle is a perpendicular line drawn from a vertex to the opposite side.
A median of a triangle connects a vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side.
In an isosceles triangle, the altitude drawn from the vertex angle also acts as a median and angle bisector.
In a right triangle, the median to the hypotenuse is half the length of the hypotenuse.
The incenter of a triangle is the point where the angle bisectors intersect and is the center of the inscribed circle.
The circumcenter of a triangle is the point where the perpendicular bisectors intersect and is the center of the circumscribed circle.
The centroid of a triangle (where medians meet) divides each median into segments with a 2:1 ratio.
The orthocenter of a triangle is the point where all three altitudes intersect.
An angle formed by two chords in a circle is half the sum of the measures of the arcs they subtend.
A secant is a line that intersects a circle in two points.
An inscribed angle in a circle is half the measure of its intercepted arc.
Regular polygons are both equiangular and equilateral.
The area of a rectangle is the product of its length and width.
The area of a triangle is half the product of its base and height.
The volume of a rectangular prism is the product of its length, width, and height.
